Name: Padded
description: This is a simple armor made of various layers of quilted cloth to absorb the force of blows.

Name: Leather
description: This is armor made of very thick leather treated with oils to give it better resistance.

Name: Armored Long Coat
description: This is armor made of treated leather but with quilted layers to give it better consistency.

Name: Fur
description: Protection made of layers of animal skins (fur). It is heavy and difficult to use.

Name: Complete Leather
description: A version of leather armor that also protects the legs. The joints are made of cloth.

Name: Hardened Leather
description: This is an armor made of leather treated with oils and unguents until it becomes completely solid.

Name: Studded Leather
description: This is a soft leather armor studded with small metal fragments. It is very useful, but difficult to wear.

Name: Chainmail
description: This is possibly the most advanced armor of its era. It is composed of fine metal rings interwoven or sewn to each other; it offers enormous protection as well as great mobility.

Name: Breastplate
description: This metal armor covers the chest and back.

Name: Partial Plate
description: Armor made of various pieces of metal that cover the most vital parts of the body. Normally they are sewn onto a suit of leather or furÂ€–Â€though sometimes this is done with joints.

Name: Byrnie
description: This is a jacket made of metal rings interlaced with each other and sewn onto a layer of stiffened leather or cloth to hold it together.

Name: Half-Plate
description: This is a complete metal armor made of dozens of pieces perfectly forged and prepared to fit into each other. It is lighter than “Full Plate,” since it sacrifices protection for mobility.

Name: Scale Mail
description: This is a leather armor covered in metal scales like those of a fish.

Name: Light Pate
description: This is heavy armor composed of a combination of metal plates over articulated joints. This has fewer pieces than Full Heavy Plate, but it also covers the entire body.

Name: Full Plate
description: These are true works of metallic art that are usually made to order. The pieces making it up cover the entire body utilizing joints of leather which are in turn covered by metal plates. Unfortunately, its weight is excessive and permits little mobility.

Name: Full Heavy Plate
description: A version of the previous type in which the metal plates have two or three times the thickness. Although it requires greater strength and skill to use, the protection it offers is much better.

Name: Full Field Plate
description: This is the heaviest and most complete of all the different types of armor. Even the joints are covered over with thick layers of metal that, although they make movement difficult, protect every bit of the anatomy.

Name: Perpunte
description:
Reinforced version of padded armor,
made to be used without additional layers.

Name: Laminar
description:
This armor
is formed by rectangular
leather plates, sewn to
each other in the form of a shirt.

Name: Brigantine
description:
Armor composed of a shirt, normally of leather, with
small, fine oblong metal plates riveted through the interior of the armor.

Name: Kozan-do
description:
Heavy oriental armor, made up of small triangles or metal
squares, joined by laces of leather or cotton.

Name: Keiko
description:
Also called Kake-yoroi, this armor is a lighter more versatile
verion of the Tanko, normally
prepared for the cavalry.

Name: O-Yoroi
description:
Is considered
heavy samurai armor par
excellence. Its shoulders are
protected by two rectangular
guards and the lower part by four aprons in a
trapezoidal form, joined with the cuirass through an
intricate system of cords and knots.

Name: Lorica Segmentata
description:
Armor composed of metallic
bands in the torso, neck and
shoulders, joined to each
other by hinges and straps of leather.

Name: Tanko
description:
Oriental armor made up essentially
of flexible long metal plates.
